\ Obviously, if the set $ {\mathop{\rm supp}\limits} h $ is central symmetric, then the function $ h^*(y) $ is even.\par

 \ We recall here the famous theorem of Fenchel-Moraux: if the function $  h = h(x)  $ is convex  and continuous,
then $  h^{**}(y) = h(y). $  \par

\ Note in addition that if the function $  h = h(x), \ x \in R^d $ is radial (spherical) function:  $ h(x) = z(|x|), $
then its Young-Fenchel transform is also radial, as well. \par

\vspace{3mm}

 \ {\bf Definition 1.4.}\par

\vspace{3mm}

 \ Recall, see \cite{Rao1}, \cite{Rao2}, \cite{Krasnosel'skii1}, that the function $  x \to g(x), \ x \in R^d, \ g(x) \in R^1_+  $
 is named multivariate Young, or Young-Orlicz function, if it is even, convex, non-negative, twice continuous differentiable,
 finite on the whole space $  R^d,$ and such that

nexttext:
\ It is easily to see that this  choice of the generating function $ \phi_{\xi} $ is optimal, but in the practical using
often this function can not  be calculated in explicit view,  but there is a possibility to estimate its. \par

 \vspace{3mm}

 \ Note that the expression for the norm $ ||\xi||B(\phi)  $ dependent aside from the function $  \phi  $
 only on the distribution $  {\mathop{\rm Law}\limits}(\xi). $ Thus, this norm and correspondent space  $  B(\phi)  $ are rearrangement invariant (symmetrical)
in the terminology of the classical book  \cite{Bennet1}, see chapters 1,2. \par

\vspace{3mm}

 \ It is proved in particular in the report \cite{Ostrovsky5} that: \\

{\sc  the space $ B(\phi) $ with respect to the norm $ || \cdot ||B(\phi) $ and
ordinary algebraic operations is a rearrangement invariant vector Banach space.} \par

 \vspace{3mm}

 \ Moreover, the proposition $ \vec{\xi} \in B(\phi)  $ may be completely adequate characterized through
the tail behavior $ U(\vec{\xi}, \vec{x}) $ as $ |x| \to \infty $ for the random vector $ \xi.  $

\vspace{3mm}

 {\bf We intend to significantly weaken  the conditions in \cite{Ostrovsky5} for tail estimates as well as for
moment estimates for random variables from these spaces. }

\vspace{3mm}

 \ {\bf Remark 1.1.} In the article of  Buldygin V.V. and Kozachenko Yu. V. \cite{Buldygin1} was
 considered a particular case when $ \phi(\lambda) = \phi^{(B)}(\lambda)  = 0.5(B\lambda,\lambda),  $ where
$  B  $  is non-degenerate positive definite symmetrical matrix, as a direct generalization of the one-dimensional one notion,
belonging to J.P.Kahane \cite{Kahane1}.  \par
 \ The correspondent random vector $ \vec{\xi}  $ was named in \cite{Buldygin1} as a subgaussian r.v. relative the
matrix $  B: $ \par

\vspace{4mm}

\section{ Main result: exponential tails behavior. } \par

\vspace{4mm}

 \hspace{5mm} We study in this section the connections between exponential decreasing tails behavior for random vectors and its
 norm in the introduced above spaces. \par

\vspace{3mm}

{\bf A. Upper estimate.} \par

\vspace{3mm}

  \ Statement of problem: let the $  B(\phi) \ -  $ norm of the non-zero random vector $ \xi \in R^d $ be a given; we can
suppose without loss of  generality $  ||\xi||B(\phi) = 1. $ We want to get the sharp  (if possible) upper bound for the tail
function $ U(\xi,x). $ \par
 \ Conversely: let for the centered random vector $ \xi = \vec{\xi} $  the its tail function $ U(\xi,x) $  (or its upper estimate)
be given; it is required to estimate its norm $  ||\xi||B(\phi)  $ in this space. \par

 \ In particular, it is required  to establish the one-to-one relation between behavior of the tail function $ U(\xi,x) $   as
$  \min_j x(j) \to \infty $ and belonging of the centered random vector $ \xi  $ to the space $  B(\phi). $ \par

 \ Note at first that when we derive the upper bounds for tail function $ U(\xi,x) $ through the $  ||\xi||B(\phi), $
 we do not need impose strong condition on the function $ \phi = \phi(\lambda). $
 \ Namely, let $  \phi = \phi(\lambda), \ \lambda \in V \subset R^d $ be arbitrary non-negative real valued function,
which is finite at last on some non-empty neighborhood $ V $ of origin. Suppose for given centered $  d  \ - $ dimensional
random vector $ \xi = \vec{\xi}  $

by virtue of theorem Fenchel-Moraux. \par

 {\bf Example 3.1.}  Suppose that the function $ \phi (\cdot)  $  is  such that for some

 {\bf Example 3.1.}  Suppose that the function $ \phi (\cdot)  $  is  such that for some
 constant $  p  > 1 $
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex80.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\phi(\lambda)=\phi_{p}(\lambda)\leq C_{1}\ |\lambda|^{p},\ |\lambda|>1." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>ϕ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mi>ϕ</mi><mi>p</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mrow><mpadded width="+5pt"><msub><mi>C</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mi>p</mi></msup></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="7.5pt">,</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mo>></mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

Then
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex81.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="|\xi|_{r}\leq C_{2}(p)\ r^{1/q}\ ||\xi||B(\phi_{r}),\ r\geq 1,\ q:=p/(p-1)," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>ξ</mi><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mi>r</mi></msub><mo>≤</mo><mrow><msub><mi>C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>p</mi><mo rspace="7.5pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+5pt"><msup><mi>r</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><mi>q</mi></mrow></msup></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo fence="true">||</mo><mi>ξ</mi><mo fence="true">||</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>ϕ</mi><mi>r</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="7.5pt">,</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mo>≥</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo rspace="7.5pt">,</mo><mrow><mi>q</mi><mo>:=</mo><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>/</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

{\bf Proposition 3.3.} Let $ \phi (\cdot) $  be arbitrary non-negative continuous function and let the centered numerical
r.v. $  \xi $  be such that $  \xi \in B(\phi): \ 0 < ||\xi|| = ||\xi||B(\phi) < \infty. $ \par

 \ Then
prevtext:
\ As a consequence: let $  \xi $ be non-zero  $ d  - $  dimensional mean zero random vector belonging to the space $  B(\phi).  $
Then
text:
$$
{\bf E} |\xi|^r \le 2^d \  \left( \frac{r}{\lambda \ e} \right)^r  \ e^{ \phi(\lambda ||\xi||) } =
2^d \ e^{-|r|} \ r^r \ \lambda^{-r} \ e^{ \phi(\lambda ||\xi||) }, \ \lambda > 0. \eqno(3.14)
$$

 \vspace{3mm}

{\sc  To summarize.}  For arbitrary centered $ d \ -  $ dimensional random vector $ \vec{\xi}  $ under formulated above, in
theorems 2.1 and 3.1 conditions the following predicated are equivalent:
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex110.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="L\cdot\exp\left(\Phi^{*}(p/\gamma)\right)." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>L</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mrow><mi>exp</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mo>*</mo></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>γ</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
\ This completes the proof of theorem 3.1. \par

 \vspace{3mm}

{\sc  To summarize.}  For arbitrary centered $ d \ -  $ dimensional random vector $ \vec{\xi}  $ under formulated above, in
theorems 2.1 and 3.1 conditions the following predicated are equivalent:

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex112.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="{\bf B.}\hskip 14.226378pt\exists C\in(0,\infty),\ U(\vec{\xi},\vec{x})\leq%
\exp\left(-\phi^{*}(\vec{x}/C)\right)." display="block"><mrow><mi>𝐁</mi><mo>.</mo><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true">  </mo><mo>∃</mo><mi>C</mi><mo>∈</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo rspace="7.5pt">,</mo><mi>U</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>ξ</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover><mo>,</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mi>exp</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>ϕ</mi><mo>*</mo></msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover><mo>/</mo><mi>C</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex113.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="{\bf C.}\hskip 14.226378pt\vec{\xi}\in G\psi_{\Phi}." display="block"><mrow><mi>𝐂</mi><mo>.</mo><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true">  </mo><mover accent="true"><mi>ξ</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover><mo>∈</mo><mi>G</mi><msub><mi>ψ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi></msub><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
\ Herewith  all the  Banach norms $ ||\xi||B(\phi), \  ||\xi|| L_{N_{\phi}} $ and $ ||\xi|| G\psi_{\Phi}  $ are
linear equivalent. \par

 \vspace{3mm}

\section{Concluding remarks.}

\vspace{3mm}

{\bf A.} To mention the possible application of obtained results. At first: a non-asymptotical {\it exponential} bounds
for the normed sums of random vectors, in the spirit of the classical article of Yu.V.Prokhorov \  \cite{Prokhorov1}, see
\ \cite{Ostrovsky5}.  Also one can derive an asymptotical and non-asymptotical analysis of  discontinuous random fields, to
generalize the main result of \ \cite{Ostrovsky6}. \par
 \ Another applications-an investigation of the Central Limit Theorem for discontinuous random fields, \ \cite{Ostrovsky7},
with further applications in the non-parametrical statistics as well as in the Monte-Carlo method \ \cite{Grigorjeva1}. \par

\vspace{3mm}

{\bf B.} It may be studied easily the case when the our considered generating Young-Orlicz function
$  \phi = \phi(\lambda), \ \lambda \in R^d $ is finite only in some convex non-trivial neighborhood $ V $ of origin,
likewise the one-dimensional case, see e.g. \cite{Kozachenko1},  \cite{Ostrovsky1}, chapter 1. \par

\vspace{3mm}

{\bf C.} The another (asymptotical) approach  for research of the non-linear functionals $  F(\xi) = F(\xi(\cdot)) $ of the random fields
may be  found in the famous survey of V.I.Piterbarg and V.R.Fatalov \ \cite{Piterbarg1}. This approach based on the investigation of
the  asymptotical behavior as $  \lambda \to 0+ $ for the {\it Laplace transform} from  the considered  functional
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex114.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="{\bf D.}\hskip 14.226378pt\vec{\xi}\in B(\phi)." display="block"><mrow><mi>𝐃</mi><mo>.</mo><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true">  </mo><mover accent="true"><mi>ξ</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover><mo>∈</mo><mi>B</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ϕ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>
